unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Healthy Teeth | 1 of 2
question_text:
Recently a random survey found that $48$ out of $100\text{ college freshmen}$ fail to brush their teeth twice a day. This compares higher than the national average of $39\%$.
What would be an appropriate interval at $99\%$ confidence to estimate the true proportion of college freshmen who do not brush their teeth twice daily?
solution:
Use the formula below to calculate a one-proportion $z$-interval. The sample proportion is $0.48$. Since the problem states this is a $99\%$ confidence interval, use tables to find the critical value $z^* = 2.576$. The sample size, $n$, is $100$.

$$\hat{p} \pm z^{*} \sqrt{\dfrac{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{n}}$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
